Nuxt file-system routing creates a route for every file in the pages/ directory.
One core feature of Nuxt is the file system router. Every Vue file inside the

directory creates a corresponding URL (or route) that displays the contents of the file. By using dynamic imports for each page, Nuxt leverages code-splitting to ship the minimum amount of JavaScript for the requested route.
and generates the routes from every component created in the
This file system routing uses naming conventions to create dynamic and nested routes:

component links pages between them. It renders an

attribute set to the route of the page. Once the application is hydrated, page transitions are performed in JavaScript by updating the browser URL. This prevents full-page refreshes and allows for animated transitions.
enters the viewport on the client side, Nuxt will automatically prefetch components and payload (generated pages) of the linked pages ahead of time, resulting in faster navigation.

Nuxt provides a customizable route middleware framework you can use throughout your application, ideal for extracting code that you want to run before navigating to a particular route.
Route middleware runs within the Vue part of your Nuxt app. Despite the similar name, they are completely different from server middleware, which are run in the Nitro server part of your app.
There are three kinds of route middleware:
Anonymous (or inline) route middleware, which are defined directly in the pages where they are used.
Named route middleware, which are placed in the
directory and will be automatically loaded via asynchronous import when used on a page. (
: The route middleware name is normalized to kebab-case, so
Global route middleware, which are placed in the
suffix) and will be automatically run on every route change.

Nuxt offers route validation via the
in each page you wish to validate.
as an argument. You can return a boolean value to determine whether or not this is a valid route to be rendered with this page. If you return
, and another match can't be found, this will cause a 404 error. You can also directly return an object with
to respond immediately with an error (other matches will not be checked).
If you have a more complex use case, then you can use anonymous route middleware instead.

<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({
  validate: async (route) => {
    // Check if the id is made up of digits
    return typeof route.params.id === 'string' && /^\d+$/.test(route.params.id)
  }
})
</script>
Validate whether a given route can validly be rendered with this page.

Return true if it is valid, or false if not. If another match can't be found,
this will mean a 404. You can also directly return an object with
statusCode/statusMessage to respond immediately with an error (other matches
will not be checked).
// Check if the id is made up of digits
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether or not a pattern exists in a searched string.
String on which to perform the search.
